Species Diversity metrics estimate the number of species in an environment. The Diversity of species is represented by a single number (index) that summarizes quantitative surveys performed in communities, sites, and samples. Several methods (indices) were developed and are frequently used in ecology and conservation studies to describe and compare biodiversity. 

This App explores and compares some of the most common Biodiversity measurements, divided here into three categories. There are models based on Richness and its indices (Margalef, Menhinick and Odum), the proportional abundance of diversity indices (Simpson, Shannon, and Evenness), and sampling size correction (Rarefaction). 

Note: It is important to mention that these models account for discrete individuals from sexual reproduction species rather than asexual systems, whose approach counts for biomass and percent cover. 



{.tabset}

Richness Indices

Species richness is simply the number of species found. It alone does not represent diversity. Communities can be described as having equal Richness but distinct diversity. For instance, green and blue communities have species 1 and 2 but differ in abundance (number of individuals). The abundance of both species in the green community is similar. It is more likely to find both species there than in the blue. Therefore, the green community is considered the most diverse.

<img src="SpDiv_ApProject/www/comm_green_blue.png" alt="green blue example" style="height: 200px; width:200px;"/>

We can confirm this difference in diversity based on richness using Margalef’s, Menhinick’s, and Odum’s indices, where S = richness; N =  total number of individuals in the sample; and In=  natural logarithm: 

\[
Margalef's Index:
\begin {align}
Mg &=\frac{(S-1)}{lnN}
\end {align}
\]

\[
Menhinick' Index:
\begin {align}
Mn &=\frac{S}{\sqrt{N}}
\end {align}
\]

\[
Odum, Cantlon, Kornicher' Index:
\begin {align}
Od &=\frac{S}{logN}
\end {align}
\]

  #### PLOTS#############

  })
  
  use_dn_rich_plt <- reactive ({
    if("Use" %in% input$dune_var){
      wrap_plots(list(dn_use_plotMg,dn_use_plotMn,dn_use_plotOd), nrow = 1) }
  })
  
  manu_dn_rich_plt <- reactive ({
    if("Manure" %in% input$dune_var){
      wrap_plots(list(dn_manu_plotMg ,dn_manu_plotMn , dn_manu_plotOd), nrow = 1) }
  })
  
  
  ######## list of the bci variables and their indices
  plot_list_dn <- reactive({
    list(moist_dn_rich_plt(), mang_dn_rich_plt(),use_dn_rich_plt(),manu_dn_rich_plt())%>% 
      discard(is.null)
  })
  
  dn_richplots_print<- reactive({
    wrap_plots(plot_list_dn(), ncol = 1)
  })
  
  #### PLOTS MITE
  
  sub_mt_rich_plt <- reactive({
    if("Substrate" %in% input$mite_var){
      wrap_plots(list(mt_subs_plotMg ,mt_subs_plotMn, mt_subs_plotOd), nrow = 1) }
  })
  
  shr_mt_rich_plt <- reactive ({
    if("Shrub" %in% input$mite_var){
      wrap_plots(list(mt_shru_plotMg, mt_shru_plotMn,mt_shru_plotOd ), nrow = 1) }
  })
  
  topo_mt_rich_plt <- reactive ({
    if("Topo" %in% input$mite_var){
      wrap_plots(list(mt_topo_plotMg , mt_topo_plotMn, mt_topo_plotOd), nrow = 1) }
  })
  
  ######## list of the bci variables and their indices
  plot_list_mt <- reactive({
    list(sub_mt_rich_plt(),shr_mt_rich_plt(),topo_mt_rich_plt())%>% 
      discard(is.null)
  })
  
  mt_richplots_print <- reactive({
    wrap_plots(plot_list_mt(), ncol = 1)
  })
  
  #### PLOTS BCI 
  
  age_bci_rich_plt <- reactive({
    if("Age.cat" %in% input$bci_var){
      wrap_plots(list(bc_age_plotMg,bc_age_plotMn, bc_age_plotOd), nrow = 1) }
  })
  
  habt_bci_rich_plt <- reactive ({
    if("Habitat" %in% input$bci_var){
      wrap_plots(list(bc_habt_plotMg,bc_habt_plotMn, bc_habt_plotOd), nrow = 1) }
  })
  
  str_bci_rich_plt <- reactive ({
    if("Stream" %in% input$bci_var){
      wrap_plots(list(bc_strm_plotMg,bc_strm_plotMn, bc_strm_plotOd), nrow = 1) }

  ######## list of the bci variables and their indices
  plot_list_bc <- reactive({
    list(age_bci_rich_plt(),habt_bci_rich_plt(),str_bci_rich_plt())%>% 
      discard(is.null)
  })
  
  bci_richplots_print <- reactive({
    wrap_plots(plot_list_bc(), ncol = 1)
  })
  
  
  
  ##### Putput plots based on the dataset chosen
  plot_rich_variables <- reactive({
    if("dune_vg" %in% input$dataset){
      dn_richplots_print()}
    else if("mite_vg" %in% input$dataset){
      mt_richplots_print()}
    else if("BCI_vg" %in% input$dataset){
      bci_richplots_print()}
  })
  output$plots_richvar = renderPlot({
    plot_rich_variables()
  })
  
  
}


shinyApp(ui = ui, server = server)

Diversity Index
 
The diversity indices relate the total abundance(N) with the abundance of each species (ni) to account for the proportion of species within the sample (pi = ni/N)...

\[
Simposon diversity Index:
\begin {align}
D &=\sum_{i=1}^{S}\left(\frac{n_i(n_i-1)}{N(N-1)}\right)
\end {align}
\]

\[
Brillouin diversity index:
\begin {align}
B = \frac{ln(N!) - \sum_{i=1}^{S}ln(n_i)!}{N}
\end {align}
\]

\[
Shannon-Wiener's diversity Index:
\begin {align}
H' &= - \sum_{i=1}^{S}\left(\frac{n_i}{N}ln\frac{n_i}{N}\right)
\end {align}
\]

\[
Evenness:
\begin {align}
E &= \frac{H'}{lnN}
\end {align}
\]
